title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In a defensive battle where points were a premium, the Indiana Pacers secured a heart-stopping 85-84 victory over the Washington Wizards, but the story of the night was a singular, historic performance lost in the final score.

Reggie Miller, the Pacers’ sharpshooting legend, authored a masterpiece for the ages, pouring in a game-high 42 points. On a night where the two teams combined for a paltry 169 points, Miller’s output was nothing short of miraculous, accounting for nearly half of his team’s entire offense. While his teammates struggled to find any consistent rhythm against a tenacious Wizards defense, Miller was a one-man offensive system, a flurry of motion and precision that Washington simply had no answer for.

The Wizards, led by Calbert Cheaney’s 19 points and a strong 17-point, 13-rebound double-double from Juwan Howard, fought valiantly. They turned this Eastern Conference clash into a grind, a possession-by-possession war where every basket was earned. Their defense was stout enough to stifle nearly every other Pacer, but Miller proved to be an unsolvable equation.

In the final, tense moments, with the game hanging in the balance, it was Miller’s relentless scoring that provided the ultimate cushion. The Wizards’ late push fell just one point short, leaving them to ponder what might have been had any other player besides Miller been similarly hot. His 42-point explosion in such a low-scoring affair transcends a simple win; it was an iconic, carry-job performance that underscored his status as one of the game’s most lethal and clutch scorers, a one-man show that ultimately decided a brutal, hard-fought contest.
